com.versant.fund
Class FundVQLQuery

java.lang.Object
  com.versant.fund.FundVQLQuery

public class FundVQLQuery
extends java.lang.Object

The class that implement queries with the VERSANT Query Language (VQL), a subset of OQLQuery as specified in ODMG 2.0.

Usage:

1. Construct a VQLQuery object using a VQL predicate string.

The VQL predicate string is a query expression that conforms to the VQL specifications. Refer to the Database Fundamentals Manual for the semantics in specifying a query expression. Result projection is not supported in this version.

The predicate string should be in the form of: 

 select selfoid from [only] class [predicate]
 update [only] class set updatelist [predicate]
 insert into class [attrlist] values [constlist]
 delete from class [predicate]

where class is the name of the class over which the query operates, only is an optional argument used if the query must exclude sub-classes from being searched, predicate is the query predicate, updatelist is a comma delimited list of individual update expressions, attrlist is an optional list of attributes in the class of the new object, and constlist is a list of values for the new object.

2. If selecting with substitution parameters, use the bind() method to assign the substitution values. The ith variable is set by the ith call to the bind() method.

3. Call method execute() to carry out the query operation and return a HandleEnumeration.

See Also:
Predicate, HandleEnumeration

select selfoid [only] from <class> [predicate]

insert into <class> [attrlist] values [constlist]

HandleEnumeration

execute

public HandleEnumeration execute(int options,
                                 int levels,
                                 int classLockMode,
                                 int instLockMode)
Executes a VQL query and return Handles in HandleEnumeration which satisfy the query statement.

The valid execution options are:

  • TOPIN Pin fetched objects in memory. To fetch objects, you must specify the Constants.FETCH_LAST option. The default is to not pin fetched objects. If you pin objects, you must later manually unpin them with unpinobj() or release them with a commit, rollback, or undosavepoint. The default is to return links but not bring the found objects into memory.
  • FLUSH_NONE Do not flush the object cache before performing the query. You cannot use both Constants.FLUSH_NONE and Constants.FLUSH_ALL. See notes for Constants.FLUSH_ALL for an explanation.
  • FLUSH_ALL Flush the object cache before performing the query. The default is to flush the dirty objects of the specified class before performing the query. You cannot use both Constants.FLUSH_NONE and Constants.FLUSH_ALL. Because queries are performed in the server process on the query database, normally you should flush the object cache so that the query evaluates and returns the latest state of each object. However, since flushing an object marks it as clean, if you modify an object again after the query you must again mark it dirty.
  • FETCH_LAST Fetch objects that satisfy the query. By default, objects that satisfy a query are not fetched from their database and placed in memory. If you have specified levels as other than zero, this option will fetch objects to the last level specified. By default, objects of last level are not fetched. Objects of intermediate levels are always fetched.
  • SELECT_DEEP Evaluate target class and it's subclasses. This is the default option for queries where the from target is a class.

For levels:

  • Specify 0 to return only the found objects.
  • Specify -1 to return all objects linked directly or indirectly to the found objects.
  • Specify a positive number to indicate the number of levels of handles to follow beginning with the found objects. For example, specify 1 to return found object and objects that are the direct target of handles in the objects found by the predicate; specify 2 to return objects that are the target of handles in the first level of linked objects.

To avoid unintentional side affects, you should normally only specify one of the following for the class lock mode:

  • Constants.IRLOCK : Intention-read lock
  • Constants.IWLOCK : Intention-write lock
  • Constants.NOLOCK : No lock

Alternatives for instance lock modes are:
  • Constants.WLOCK : Write lock
  • Constants.RIWLOCK : Read/intention-write lock
  • Constants.IWLOCK : Intention-write lock
  • Constants.ULOCK : Update lock
  • Constants.RLOCK : Read lock
  • Constants.IRLOCK : Intention-read lock
  • Constants.NOLOCK : No lock

Parameters:
options - The execution options.
levels - The number of select levels.
classLockMode - The short lock to be placed on the class object.
instLockMode - The lock to be placed on returned instances.
See Also:
SelectBuilder, HandleEnumeration

executeWithCursor

public HandleEnumeration executeWithCursor(int batchSize)
Execute the VQL query and return handles to objects that satisfy the query statement using a database cursor. A cursor query that selects objects returns a HandleEnumeration just as a VQL execute method does. In addition, it creates a cursor that fetches handles to objects from the database one batch at a time, where the batch size is according to the supplied argument.

Cursor query does not support selection from single object.

In iterating through the HandleEnumeration using the Handle nextHandle() method, the cursor is transparently advanced to fetch the next batch of handles to objects.

By fetching batches of object at a time using a cursor rather than all the objects at once, a cursor query reduces lock contention on the fetched objects and lessens memory usage.

When you finish using a cursor you must invalidate it to release it. This can be done by invoking the invalidateCursor() method on the HandleEnumeration instance. All open cursors are automatically released at the end of each transaction.

To use a cursor based VQL query, you can do the following: 

     FundVQLQuery query = new FundVQLQuery (session,
                   "select selfoid from Person where age < 18);
     HandleEnumeration people = query.executeWithCursor(100);
       while (people.hasMoreHandles()) {
         HandleVector hv = people.nextBatch();
         HandleEnumeration he = hv.handles();
         while(he.hasMoreHandles()){
           Handle h = he.nextHandle();
           // use handle h
         }
       }
      people.invalidateCursor ();

Parameters:
batchSize - the number of elements to fetch in a cursor batch
See Also:
HandleEnumeration

executeWithCursor

public HandleEnumeration executeWithCursor(int options,
                                           int classLockMode,
                                           int instLockMode,
                                           int batchSize)
Execute the VQL query and return handles to objects that satisfy the query statement using a database cursor. A cursor query that selects objects returns a HandleEnumeration just as a VQL execute option without a cursor batch size does. In addition, it creates a cursor that fetches objects from the database one batch at a time, where the batch size is according to the supplied argument.

Cursor query does not support selection from single object.

In iterating through the HandleEnumeration using the nextHandle() method, the cursor is transparently advanced to fetch the next batch of handles to objects.

By fetching batches of object at a time using a cursor rather than all the objects at once, a cursor query reduces lock contention on the fetched objects and lessens memory usage.

When you finish using a cursor you must invalidate it to release it. This can be done by invoking the invalidateCursor() method on the VEnumeration instance. All open cursors are automatically released at the end of each transaction.

To use a cursor based VQL query, you can do the following: 

     FundVQLQuery query = new FundVQLQuery (session,
                "select selfoid from Person where age < 18);
     HandleEnumeration people = query.executeWithCursor(0,
                                                        Constants.IRLOCK,
                                                        Constants.NOLOCK,
                                                        100);//batchSize
     while (people.hasMoreHandles()) {
         HandleVector hv = people.nextBatch();
         HandleEnumeration he = hv.handles();
         while(he.hasMoreHandles()){
             Handle h = he.nextHandle();
             // use Handle h
         }
     }

     people.invalidateCursor();

Parameters:
options - select options
classLockMode - lock mode to place on class objects
instLockMode - lock mode to place on selected instances
batchSize - the number of elements to fetch in a cursor batch
See Also:
HandleEnumeration
